standard_metadata.standard_description: Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.

question.content: Gina made $9{,}350 \text{ mL}$ of lentil soup.  She and her kids ate $1.8 \text{ L}$ of the soup for lunch.  **How  many *milliliters* of soup did Gina have leftover?**     $\text{mL}$

hints.content: First, we need to convert $\blueE{1.8}\text{ L}$ to milliliters.  $1 \text{ L} = 1{,}000\text{ mL}$.  So,  $\begin{align} \blueE{1.8}\text{ L}&={\blueE{1.8}}\text{ L} \times {1{,}000}\text{ mL per L} \\\\ &= \blueE{1{,}800} \text{ mL} \end{align}$

Now, we need to find out how much soup Gina had leftover.  Gina had a total of $\purpleE{9{,}350}\text{ mL}$ of soup. She and her kids ate $\blueE{1{,}800}\text{ mL}$ of soup.  [[☃ image 2]]  $\blueE{1{,}800}\text { mL}~ +~ \maroonD{?}\text { mL} = {}\purpleE{9{,}350}\text{ mL}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 9,350. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total milliliters of soup. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 1,800. The second part is labeled question mark. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled milliliters of soup for lunch. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled milliliters of soup leftover.

hints.content: Gina had $\maroonD{7{,}550}\text{ mL}$ of soup leftover.   [[☃ image 2]]  $\blueE{1{,}800}\text { mL}~ +~ \maroonD{7{,}550}\text { mL} = {}\purpleE{9{,}350}\text{ mL}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 9,350. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total milliliters of soup. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 1,800. The second part is labeled 7,550. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled milliliters of soup for kids. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled milliliters of soup to freeze.

hints.content: Gina had ${7{,}550} \text{ mL}$ of soup leftover.

question.content: George filled $10$ mugs with coffee. He filled each mug with $240\text{ mL}$ of coffee.  **How many *liters* of coffee did George use in total?**     $\text{L}$

hints.content: George filled $10$ cups with $240\text{ mL}$ each.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{240}\text{ mL}\times\tealE{10}=~\purpleD{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. The bottom rectangle is divided into 10 equal parts, each labeled 240. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 10 equal groups.

hints.content: George used $\purpleD{2{,}400}\text{ mL}$ of coffee.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{240}\text{ mL}\times\tealE{10}=~\purpleD{2{,}400}\text{ mL}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 2400. The bottom rectangle is divided into 10 equal parts, each labeled 240. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 10 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\purpleD{2{,}400}\text{ mL}$ to liters.  $1 \text{ mL} = \dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ L}$  So,  $\begin {align}{\purpleD{2{,}400} \text{ mL}}&= {\purpleD{2{,}400}  \text{  mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{\purpleD{2{,}400}  \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\purpleD{2{,}400} \text{ L} }{1{,}000}\\\\ &=\purpleD{2{,}400} \text{ L}\div1{,}000\\\\ &=\purpleD{2.4}\text{ L} \end{align}$
George used $\purpleD{2.4} \text{ L}$ of coffee.

question.content: Coach Jill brought $28 \text{ L}$ of sports drink to the soccer game. She divided the sports drink equally between $7$ coolers.    **How  many *milliliters* of  sports drink did Coach Jill put in each cooler?**     $\text{mL}$

hints.content: Coach Jill divided $28 \text{ L}$ into $7$ equal parts.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{28}\text{ L } \div \tealE7 = {}\maroonD{?}\text{ L}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 28. The bottom rectangle is divided into 7 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 7 equal groups.

hints.content: Each cooler contained $\maroonD4 \text{ L}$ of sports drink.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{28}\text{ L } \div \tealE7 = \maroonD{4}\text{ L}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 28. The bottom rectangle is divided into 7 equal parts, each labeled 4. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 7 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\maroonD4\text{ L}$ to milliliters.  $1 \text{ L} = 1{,}000\text{ mL}$.  So,  $\begin{align} \maroonD4\text{ L}&=\maroonD4\text{ L} \times {1{,}000}\text{ mL per L}\\\\  &= \maroonD{4{,}000} \text{ mL} \end{align}$
Coach Jill put $\maroonD{4{,}000} \text{ mL}$ of sports drink in each cooler.

question.content: Jim has $19{,}700\text { g}$ of sand in his sandbox.  He brings home another $6{,}300\text { g}$ of sand from the beach to add to his sandbox.     **How  many *kilograms* of  sand does Jim have in his sandbox now?**     $\text{kg}$

hints.content: Jim had $\blueE{19{,}700}\text { g}$ of sand and added  $\maroonD{6{,}300}\text { g}$ more.     [[☃ image 1]]    $\blueE{19{,}700}\text { g} + \maroonD{6{,}300}\text { g} = {}\purpleE{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total grams of sand. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 19,700. The second part is labeled 6,300. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled Sandbox sand. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled Beach sand.

hints.content: Jim has $\purpleE{26{,}000}\text { g}$ of sand in his sandbox.   [[☃ image 1]]    $\blueE{19{,}700}\text { g} + \maroonD{6{,}300}\text { g} = {}\purpleE{26{,}000}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 26,000. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total grams of sand. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 19,700. The second part is labeled 6,300. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled Sandbox sand. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled Beach sand.

hints.content: We need to convert $\purpleE{26{,}000}\text { g}$ to kilograms.    $1 \text{ g}=\dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ kg}$  $\begin{align} \purpleE{26{,}000} \text{ kg}&=\purpleE{26{,}000}\text{ g}\times\dfrac{1\text{ kg}}{1{,}000\text{ g}}\\\\ &=\purpleE{26{,}000}\cancel{\text{ g}}\times\dfrac{1\text{ kg}}{1{,}000\cancel{\text{ g}}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\purpleE{26{,}000}\text{ kg}}{1{,}000}\\\\ &={\purpleE{26{,}000}\text{ kg}}\div{1{,}000}\\\\ &=\purpleE{26}\text{ kg} \end{align}$
Jim has $\purpleE{26}\text{ kg}$ of sand in his sandbox.

question.content: Ally sliced $32 \text{ kg}$ of watermelon for a party.  She divided the watermelon slices equally between $8$ large bowls.   **How  many *grams* of  watermelon did Ally put in each bowl?**     $\text{g}$

hints.content: Ally divided $32 \text{ kg}$ of watermelon into $8$ large bowls.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{32}\text{ kg} \div \tealE8 = {}\maroonD{?}\text{ kg}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 32. The bottom rectangle is divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 8 equal groups.

hints.content: Each bowl had $\maroonD4 \text{ kg}$ of watermelon.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{32}\text{ kg} \div \tealE8 = {}\maroonD{4}\text{ kg}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 32. The bottom rectangle is divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled 4. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 8 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\maroonD4\text{ kg}$ to grams.  $1 \text{ kg} = 1{,}000\text{ g}$.  So,  $\begin{align} \maroonD4\text{ kg}&=\maroonD4\text{ kg} \times {1{,}000}\text{ kg per g}\\\\  &= \maroonD{4{,}000} \text{ kg} \end{align}$
Ally put $\maroonD{4{,}000} \text{ g}$ of watermelon into each bowl.

question.content: At science camp, the kitchen served half of their blueberries with breakfast.  After dinner, they served the remaining $5{,}270 \text{ g}$ of blueberries with dessert.      **How many *kilograms* of blueberries did the science camp begin with in total?**      kilograms

hints.content: The kitchen served half of their blueberries with breakfast and half with dessert. They served $5{,}270\text{ g}$ of blueberries at each meal.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{5{,}270}\text{ g} + \maroonD{5{,}270}\text{ g} = ~\purpleE{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total grams of berries. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 equal parts, each labeled 5,270. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled grams of berries for breakfast. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled grams of berries for dessert.

hints.content: The kitchen served $\purpleE{10{,}540}\text{ g}$ of blueberries.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{5{,}270}\text{ g} + \maroonD{5{,}270}\text{ g} = ~\purpleE{10{,}540}\text{ g}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 10,540. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total grams of berries. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 equal parts, each labeled 5,270. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled grams of berries for breakfast. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled grams of berries for dessert.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\purpleE{10{,}540}\text{ g}$ to kilograms.  $\begin {align}{\purpleE{10{,}540}\text{ g}}&= \purpleE{10{,}540}\text{ g}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \text{ g}}}  \\\\ &= {\dfrac{\purpleE{10{,}540} \cancel{\text{ g}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ g}}}}  \\\\ &= \dfrac{{\purpleE{10{,}540} \text{ kg}}}{{1{,}000}}  \\\\ &= {\purpleE{10{,}540} \text{ kg}}\div{1{,}000} \\\\ &={\purpleE{10.54}\text{ kg}}\end{align}$
The science camp began with $\purpleE{10.54}\text{ kg}$ of blueberries in total.

question.content: It is $3{:}32\text{ p.m.}$ and Emma has gymnastics lessons at $6{:}00\text{ p.m.}$   **How many *minutes* are there until Emma's gymnastics lessons?**   minutes

hints.content: Let's find out how much time there is between $3{:}32\text{ p.m.}$ and $6{:}00\text{ p.m.}$   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from 3 o'clock to 6 o'clock with tick marks every one hour. A tick mark at 3:32 is labeled.

hints.content: Let's add minutes until we get to the next hour, $4{:}00\text{ p.m.}$    [[☃ image 1]]    It is $\blueE{28}$ minutes until $4{:}00\text{ p.m.}$

images.alt: A number line from 3 o'clock to 6 o'clock with tick marks every one hour. An arrow labeled plus 28 minutes runs along the number line from the tick mark 3:32 to the tick mark 4.

hints.content: Now, let's find out how many hours are between $4{:}00\text{ p.m.}$ and $6{:}00\text{ p.m.}$  [[☃ image 1]]  There are $\maroonD{2}$ hours between $4{:}00\text{ p.m.}$ and $6{:}00\text{ p.m.}$

images.alt: A number line from 3 o'clock to 6 o'clock with tick marks every one hour. An arrow labeled plus 28 minutes runs along the number line from the tick mark 3:32 to the tick mark 4. Another arrow labeled plus 2 hours moves right along the number line from tick mark 4 to tick mark 6:00.

hints.content: Now, lets convert $2$ hours and $28$ minutes into only minutes.  $1$ hours = $60$ minutes.  $2\text{ hours}\times60\text{ minutes per hour} = 120 \text{ minutes}$
$120 \text{ minutes} + 28\text{ minutes} = 148\text{ minutes}$
There are $148\text{ minutes}$ until Emma's gymnastics lessons.

question.content: Kristen gets home from work at $5{:}34\text{ p.m.}$ Kristen's dinner is ready at $5{:}51\text{ p.m.}$  **How many *seconds* after Kristen gets home is her dinner ready?**   seconds

hints.content: Let's find out how many minutes are between $5{:}34\text{ p.m.}$ and $5{:}51\text{ p.m.}$   [[☃ image 1]]    Kristen has $\blueE{17}$ minutes until dinner.

images.alt: A number line from 5:34 to 5:51. An arrow labeled plus 17 minutes runs along the number line from tick mark 5:34 to tick mark 5:51.

hints.content: Now, lets convert $17$ minutes into seconds.  $1$ minute = $60$ seconds.  $17\text{ minutes} \times 60\text{ seconds per minute} = 1{,}020 \text{ seconds}$
Kristen's dinner is ready $1{,}020\text{ seconds}$ after she gets home.

question.content: It takes Andrew $720$ seconds to take a shower. He spends an additional $420$ seconds eating breakfast.  **How many minutes does it take Andrew to take a shower and eat breakfast?**   minutes

hints.content: Andrew takes $\blueE{720}\text { seconds}$ to take a shower and $\maroonD{420}\text { seconds}$ to eat breakfast.    [[☃ image 1]]    $\blueE{720}\text { seconds} + \maroonD{420}\text { seconds} = {}\purpleE{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total time getting ready. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 720. The second part is labeled 420. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled shower. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled breakfast.

hints.content: It takes Andrew $\purpleE{1{,}140}\text{ seconds}$ to shower and eat breakfast in the morning.    [[☃ image 1]]    $\blueE{720}\text { seconds} + \maroonD{420}\text { seconds} = {}\purpleE{1{,}140}\text{ seconds}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 1,140. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total time getting ready. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 720. The second part is labeled 420. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled shower. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled breakfast.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\purpleE{1{,}140}\text{ seconds}$ to minutes.  $1$ second = $\dfrac{1}{60}$ minute.  So,  $\begin{align} \purpleE{1{,}140}\text{ seconds} &= \purpleE{1{,}140}\text{ seconds}\times\dfrac{1\text{ second}}{60\text{ seconds per minute}}\\\\ &= {\dfrac{\purpleE{1{,}140} \cancel{\text{ seconds}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ minute}}{{60 \cancel{\text{ seconds}}}} \\\\ &= {\dfrac{\purpleE{1{,}140}\text{ minutes}}{60}} \\\\ &=\purpleE{1{,}140}\text{ minutes}\div 60\\\\ &=\purpleE{19}\text{ minutes} \end{align}$
It takes Andrew $\purpleE{19}\text{ minutes}$ to shower and eat breakfast.

question.content: A butterfly flew $743 \text{ cm}$ and landed on a rose. Then the butterfly flew another $567 \text { cm}$ to go to a daisy.  **How  many *meters* did the butterfly fly in total?**     meters

hints.content: The butterfly flew $\blueE{743}\text { cm}$ and then flew $\maroonD{567}\text{ cm}$ more.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{743}\text { cm} + \maroonD{567}\text { cm} = {}\purpleE{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total centimeters flown. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 743. The second part is labeled 567. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled centimeters flown to rose. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled centimeters flown to daisy.

hints.content: The butterfly flew $\purpleE{1{,}310}\text { cm}$ in total.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 1,310. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total centimeters flown. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 743. The second part is labeled 567. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled centimeters flown to rose. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled centimeters flown to daisy.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\purpleE{1{,}310}\text { cm}$ to meters.  $1 \text{ m}=100\text{ cm}$ so, $1\text{ cm} = \dfrac{1\text{ m}}{100\text{ cm}}$  $\begin{align} \purpleE{1{,}310} \text{ cm}&={\purpleE{1{,}310}}\text{ cm}\times\dfrac{1\text{ m}}{100\text{ cm}}\\\\ &={\purpleE{1{,}310}}\cancel{\text{ cm}}\times\dfrac{1\text{ m}}{100\cancel{\text{ cm}}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\purpleE{1{,}310}\text{ m}}{100}\\\\ &={\purpleE{1{,}310}\text{ m}}\div{100}\\\\ &=\purpleE{13.1}\text{ m} \end{align}$
The butterfly flew $\purpleE{13.1}$ meters in total.

question.content: Adam went on a $54 \text { km}$ hike.  He divided the hike evenly over $6$ days.    **How  many *meters* did Adam hike on each day?**      meters

hints.content: Adam hiked $54\text{ km}$ over $6$ days.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{54}\text{ km} \div \tealE6 = {}\maroonD{?}\text{ km}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 54. The bottom rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 6 equal groups.

hints.content: Adam hiked $\maroonD9 \text{ km}$ each day.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{54}\text{ km} \div \tealE6 = \maroonD{9}\text{ km}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 54. The bottom rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled 9. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 6 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\maroonD9\text{ km}$ to meters.  $1 \text{ km} = 1{,}000\text{ m}$.  So,  $\begin{align} \maroonD9\text{ km}&=\maroonD9\text{ km} \times {1{,}000}\text{ m per km}\\\\  &= \maroonD{9{,}000} \text{ m} \end{align}$
Adam hiked $\maroonD{9{,}000} \text{ m}$ each day.

question.content: Tessa is training for a marathon. She runs $13\text{ km}$ each day for $3$ days.  **How  many *meters* did Tessa run in total?**      meters

hints.content: Tessa ran $13\text{ km}$ each day for $3$ days.    [[☃ image 1]]  $ \tealE{3} \times{}\maroonD{13}\text{ km} = ~\purpleD{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 equal parts, each labeled 13. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 3 equal groups.

hints.content: Tessa ran a total of $\purpleD{39} \text{ km}$.    [[☃ image 1]]  $ \tealE{3} \times{}\maroonD{13}\text{ km} = ~\purpleD{39}\text{ km}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 39. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 equal parts, each labeled 13. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 3 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\purpleD{39}\text{ km}$ to meters.  $1 \text{ km} = 1{,}000\text{ m}$.  So,  $\begin{align} \purpleD{39}\text{ km}&=\purpleD{39}\text{ km} \times {1{,}000}\text{ m per km}\\\\  &= \purpleD{39{,}000} \text{ m} \end{align}$
Tessa ran a total of $\purpleD{39{,}000} \text{ m}$.
